content: Digital Arrest Scams involve fraudsters posing as law enforcement (CBI, Police, Customs). They claim the victim's Aadhaar or bank account is linked to a crime (drug trafficking, money laundering). They force the victim to stay on a video call ('Digital Arrest'), which is NOT a real legal procedure in India. Real police never interrogate via video call or demand money for 'verification'.
legal_info: Impersonating a public servant is a crime under Section 170 IPC. 'Digital Arrest' has no legal basis in the Bhartiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS) or CrPC.

content: UPI Scams often involve 'request money' links disguised as refunds or cashback. Remember: UPI PIN is ONLY needed to SEND money, never to receive it. If someone asks you to enter your PIN to receive a prize, it is a scam.
legal_info: Unauthorized access to computer resource is punishable under Section 66C & 66D of the IT Act, 2000.

content: Tech Support Scams display fake virus popups claiming your computer is infected. They ask you to call a number and install remote access software (AnyDesk, TeamViewer). Legitimate companies like Microsoft never call you unsolicited to fix your computer.
legal_info: Cheating by personation is punishable under Section 419 IPC (or Section 319 BNS).

content: Bank KYC Scams send SMS warning that your account will be blocked unless you update KYC immediately via a link. Banks never send links for KYC updates via SMS. These links lead to phishing sites.
legal_info: Phishing is a cyber offence under Section 66 IT Act.

content: Lottery Scams claim you won a massive prize but must pay a small 'processing fee' or 'tax' first. Legitimate lotteries never ask winners to pay money to release the prize.
legal_info: Advance fee fraud falls under Section 420 IPC (Cheating).

content: Sextortion involves threatening to release compromising videos (often fake or recorded during a video call) unless money is paid. Do not pay. Report to cybercrime.gov.in immediately.
legal_info: Extortion is punishable under Section 384 IPC (Section 308 BNS). Publishing private images without consent is under Section 66E IT Act.
